nodes.text: Differences in colonial-era settler mortality generated exogenous variation in institutions that explains large cross-country differences in modern income per capita

Premise 1: Europeans adopted different colonization policies producing different institutions: settler colonies created pro-property-rights institutions while nonsettler colonies created extractive institutions
Premise 2: Feasibility of European settlement depended on local disease environment; high European mortality reduced settlement likelihood
Premise 3: Colonial institutions persisted after independence and shaped current institutions

Method: Use nineteenth- and earlier-century European mortality rates (soldiers, bishops, sailors) as an instrument for current institutions and estimate institutions' effect on log GDP per capita using two-stage least squares
Evidence (first-stage): Log settler mortality is strongly negatively correlated with current protection-against-expropriation index (mortality explains ~25–30% of variation in institutions)

Evidence: European settlements (fraction of European descent in 1900) are positively associated with early institutions (constraints on executive, democracy circa 1900), and early institutions strongly correlate with institutions today

Context / Evidence on disease biology: Malaria and yellow fever caused high mortality among nonimmune Europeans but much lower mortality among indigenous adults due to acquired immunity and genetic traits

Result (IV): Two-stage least-squares estimate implies large, statistically significant effect of institutions on log income per capita (baseline IV coefficient ~0.94; improving institutions has large predicted income gains)

Method / Data: Mortality measures compiled mainly from Philip Curtin (military/naval mortality) and supplementary sources (bishops, local records); institutions proxied by Political Risk Services expropriation index (1985–1995) and Polity measures for early institutions

Evidence (robustness): IV results are robust to excluding Neo-Europes and Africa, to controls for latitude, climate, religion, legal origin, colonizer identity, natural resources, soil types, ethnolinguistic fragmentation, current disease measures, and percent European descent

Overidentification and placebo checks: Using additional instruments (settlements, early institutions, yellow fever history) and overidentification tests find no evidence that settler mortality has a direct effect on income outside its effect through institutions

Limitation / Assumption: Exclusion restriction assumes historical settler mortality affects current GDP only via institutions; potential threats include measurement error in instruments, possible channels other than institutions, and endogenous modern disease prevalence

Conclusion: Colonial settler mortality plausibly generated exogenous institutional variation, and instrumental-variable estimates indicate institutions have a large causal impact on modern cross-country income differences, implying potential large gains from institutional improvement
